awd_titl_txt: Advanced Technological Education in the Intelligent Infrastructure for the Industrial Internet-of-Things
awd_abstract_narration:
The speed of technological innovation in the 21st century requires companies to work across levels, functions, and locations, so they can use new technologies and solve problems quickly. Consequently, industries increasingly need teams of workers who can fill multiple roles and communicate clearly with others, while performing a variety of tasks. This collaborative, flexible work environment is supported by an Intelligent Industrial Internet-of-Things (I4T), a sophisticated network of machines, systems, and humans that work together to manufacture goods. This project will develop and deploy an online learning platform and curriculum to prepare skilled technicians to work effectively in I4T settings. Working in cross-functional teams assigned to hands-on projects, students will learn to use a shared vocabulary, and to work effectively and collaboratively in diverse teams. The training aims to establish a pipeline of manufacturing technicians who can use technologies for competitive advantages. 

This project aims to develop, pilot, refine, and deliver interdisciplinary team-based training on I4T systems for manufacturing. To achieve these goals, the project aims to develop learning modules to support training in Rapid Prototyping, Lean Production, Just-In-Time Inventory Management, and Predictive Maintenance/Reduced Downtime; these learning modules will also form an integral part of a Prototype Design degree. The faculty developing the learning modules will collaborate with Instructional Designers on curriculum design. Experts in advanced manufacturing and automated guided vehicles will provide subject matter expertise, to ensure that modules are relevant to industry needs.  The learning modules will feature hands-on, problem-based activity kits designed to train both high school and college students to work with I4T. Industry partners will provide both hardware, such as sensors and web-based dashboards, and the expertise required to develop real life scenarios across the four topic areas. The cost of individual kits will be kept low by using readily available materials. Teams of high school and college teachers will be invited to participate in Train-the-Trainer workshops, to learn how to deploy the learning modules at their schools. The trainers will subsequently offer a series of one-day workshops and three-day summer boot camps to middle school, high school, and college students. Faculty will be trained to incorporate the platform and modules across production-related programs. In addition, they will receive training in problem-based learning techniques and ways to engage women. The low cost and supportive training should facilitate adoption by other institutions. Resources and results will be disseminated broadly through venues such as Hi-Tech annual conferences, the National Convergence Technology Center, the ATE Central website, and professional research journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project NEXUS was a partnership between education and industry for enhancing manufacturing technician training on the Intelligent Infrastructure for the Industrial Internet of Things (I4T).  Within this context NEXUS operated across all four years of funding (3 years of grant funded operation and one no-cost extension year) to address the NSF ATE focus areas of ?Curriculum and Educational Materials Development? and ?Professional Development for Educators.?  The goal of NEXUS was that the lead institution, Metropolitan Community College (MCC), and our partners would develop, test, deliver, and disseminate a model and resources for interdisciplinary, contextualized, and inclusive outreach and technician training to support I4T in a manufacturing setting. Two key project objectives to operationalize the goal included: 1) to develop, pilot, refine and deliver interdisciplinary, contextualized, and inclusive team-based outreach and training on I4T systems for Manufacturing, and 2) to sustain, disseminate, and support the expanded adoption of NEXUS strategies and resources.  An extensive evaluation process was led by a senior faculty member at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.  All deliverables were achieved and shifts to online environments to address the pandemic safety contexts were also accomplished successfully.

The Intellectual Merit of NEXUS was its advance of a transformative model for the interdisciplinary design and delivery of STEM technician training. NEXUS steadily shifted the faculty role from subject matter experts (SMEs) and sources of knowledge to collaborators and co-facilitators of real-world learning experiences. NEXUS used a team-based model for learning design (faculty, SMEs, industry partners, an instructional designer, and a project manager) to build a program that could be flexibly integrated across both youth and adult instruction. For Broader Impacts, the NEXUS project continued to respond directly to the local, statewide, regional, and national needs of industry and educators, including how to shift training to hybrid and online instruction, with problem-solving oriented simulations that could be done online as well as with hands-on kits to meet pandemic safety precautions.  The NEXUS team also contributed to numerous conferences, professional conversations, and disseminations across all four years.

The overall outcomes of the NEXUS program included the following:

1)    A fully developed, piloted, refined, and well-documented I4T curriculum with opportunities to deliver it within in-person, hybrid, and online formats.

2)    A wide array of student engagements over the four years, including course integrations in college classes, high school classes, and youth STEM camps.

3)    The development of student problem solving related online simulations, as well as hands-on kits from easily attainable materials such as commercial sensors and standard hair dryers.

4)    The facilitation of numerous local, state, and national level presentations and workshops, such as at the ATE PI and HITEC national conferences, which also included YouTube videos that can also support instruction.

5)    The evolution into being a leading voice within the area for how to successfully navigate the needed online and hybrid instructional environments within shutdowns such as experienced during the pandemic.

6)    The receipt of awards for instructional innovation, such as the prestigious National Council for Workforce Education Noncredit Exemplary Program Award.
